reviewText: Jan Schmidt-Garre is music documentarian who has made films about Bruckner, Furtwngler and Celibidache, among others, and who has also begun a series of films about pianists, among which are those about Marc-Andr Hamelin Marc-Andr Hamelin: No Limits - The World of the Piano, Vol. 2, Pierre-Laurent Aimard Legato: The World of the Piano: Pierre-Laurent Aimard - Not Just One Truth and Boris Berezovsky Legato: the World of the Piano: Boris Berezovsky [DVD Video], all of which are outstanding and all of which further our understanding of 'the world of the piano'. Now comes a documentary about the Swedish pianist Roland Pntinen. The film consists of a 'Portrait' (30 mins) that shows the pianist getting ready for a concert in 2007 at the Ruhr Piano Festival and in particular working with composer Kaija Saariaho on the premire of her piece Prlude and Ballade, and 'Concert' (75 mins) of that recital, and an interview with Schmidt-Garre (an excellent and very knowledgeable interviewer; 65 mins) talking with Pntinen. There is also a 'bonus' of Pntinen playing an Ignaz Friedman piano transcription of the 'Schatz-Walzer' of Johann Strauss jr. The concert has an eclectic program: Couperin: Les Baricades mistrieuses Rameau: Gavotte in A minor with 6 doubles Busoni: Albumblatt; Elegien: Turandots Frauengemach - Die Nachtlichen; Toccata Kaija Saariaho: Prlude - Ballade Chopin: Ballade No. 4 in F minor Albniz: Iberia: Rondea - Triana Rachmaninov: Morceaux de fantaisie: Srnade Ravel: Miroirs: Oiseaux tristes Pntinen is a fine pianist but in my opinion is not on the same exalted level as the three pianists whose documentaries preceded his. Also, in the conversation with Schmidt-Garre his manner of speaking, although thoughtful and informative, is so slow and hesitant that it becomes a bit of a difficulty staying with it. Hence, the four star rating. But the live concert itself is really quite good and worth seeing and hearing, although I could never bring myself to particularly enjoy the Saariaho pieces. One could only hope that Schmidt-Garre could make a documentary about Grigoriy Sokolov, surely one of the greatest pianists of our time, but Sokolov's shyness and difficult personality probably make that an impossibility. How about Stephen Hough, Mr Schmidt-Garre? Scott Morrison
